content: Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with service in the armed forces and exposure to toxic agents under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Project 112. The new section added to title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, ensuring that certain diagnosed diseases are considered to have been incurred or aggravated by service, even without evidence during the period of such service. The new section in title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112. Any diagnosed disease with increased exposure to toxic agents related to military service is considered to have been incurred or aggravated by service, even without evidence during that period. The new section in title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, where a disease becomes manifest within a prescribed period in a veteran who was exposed to toxic agents during military service. The new section in title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, where a veteran who served on active duty and was exposed to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 develops a disease. Veterans exposed to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 and develop associated diseases are presumed to have been exposed to toxic agents unless proven otherwise. Veterans exposed to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 and develop associated diseases are presumed to have been exposed to toxic agents unless proven otherwise. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases covered by determinations made under this section. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases linked to exposure to toxic agents during military service, based on sound medical and scientific evidence. The Secretary will make determinations based on sound medical and scientific evidence for a positive association between exposure to toxic agents during military service and diagnosed diseases in humans or animals. The Secretary will consider all medical and scientific information available, including statistical significance, replication capability, and peer review, when determining if a veteran was exposed to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 and if a diagnosed disease occurred in humans or animals. The Secretary will consider all medical and scientific information available, including statistical significance, replication capability, and peer review, when evaluating the association between disease occurrence and exposure to toxic agents in humans or animals. For the purpose of evaluating the association between disease occurrence and exposure to toxic agents, credible evidence outweighing the evidence against the association is considered positive. If the presumption of service connection for a disease is removed, veterans awarded compensation before the removal will continue to receive it. Whenever the presumption of service connection for a disease is removed, veterans awarded compensation before the removal will continue to receive it, along with survivors entitled to dependency and indemnity compensation. Veterans and survivors entitled to compensation for diseases related to Project 112 will continue to receive it even after the presumption of service connection is removed. The term 'Project 112' refers to the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD. Veterans and survivors entitled to compensation for diseases related to Project 112 will continue to receive it even after the presumption of service connection is removed. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses related to chemical or biological warfare tests or projects, including Project 112, will be maintained for veterans and survivors entitled to compensation. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must create regulations within 180 days to notify veterans potentially exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. The Secretary of Defense must provide all records of personnel exposed to such agents within 30 days. A report must be submitted within 1 year of enactment. The Secretary of Defense must provide all records of personnel exposed to biological or chemical agents to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. A report on Project 112, including costs and challenges, must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of enactment. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must submit a report to Congress on Project 112. The report should document costs, benefits, and challenges of finding more Project 112 participants, provide information on all known participants, and address concerns from the Department of Veterans Affairs, veterans, and veterans service organizations. Project 112, a chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD, requires a report to Congress detailing costs, benefits, challenges, and providing information on all participants. The report must also address concerns from the Department of Veterans Affairs, veterans, and veterans service organizations.
